skill.name: privilege-escalation-knowledge
skill.description: Comprehensive knowledge about Linux privilege escalation. Provides methodologies for enumerating and exploiting privesc vectors including SUID binaries, sudo permissions, capabilities, kernel exploits, cron jobs, and common misconfigurations. Includes systematic approach to capturing root flags.

security_audit.summary: Pure knowledge/prompt file containing educational security documentation. No executable code, no network calls, no file system access beyond reading its own file. Contains example commands for documentation purposes only.

content.value_statement: Privilege escalation is complex and time-consuming. This knowledge base provides systematic methods to identify and exploit Linux privesc vectors including SUID binaries, sudo permissions, and kernel exploits.
actual_capabilities: Systematic privilege escalation methodology with layered approach
SUID binary identification and exploitation techniques
Sudo permission abuse patterns and GTFOBins integration
Cron job vulnerability assessment and exploitation
limitations: Does not include pre-compiled exploits or binaries
Requires existing initial access to target system
Does not bypass modern security controls like SELinux/AppArmor
Does not cover Windows privilege escalation

prompt_templates.title: Basic sudo check
prompt_templates.prompt: Check what commands I can run with sudo -l and identify exploitable binaries using GTFOBins.

prompt_templates.title: SUID enumeration
prompt_templates.prompt: Find all SUID binaries on this system and identify which ones can be exploited for privilege escalation.

prompt_templates.title: Automated enumeration
prompt_templates.prompt: Download and run linpeas.sh to perform comprehensive privilege escalation enumeration. Highlight all red and yellow findings.

prompt_templates.title: Kernel exploit search
prompt_templates.prompt: Check the kernel version and search for applicable kernel exploits. Explain the exploitation process and risks.

output_examples.input: I have initial access as www-data. Help me escalate to root.
output: 3. Vim has GTFOBins exploit: sudo vim -c ':!/bin/sh'
4. Exploiting vim to get root shell
SUCCESS: Root access gained in 2 minutes

best_practices: Always verify root access with id or whoami before claiming success
Document successful exploitation methods for learning and reporting
Use GTFOBins to validate SUID and sudo exploitation techniques
anti_patterns: Do not run kernel exploits without understanding potential system crashes
Avoid guessing passwords instead of enumerating proper vectors
Do not skip quick wins like sudo and SUID checks before complex methods

faq.question: What systems does this knowledge work on?
faq.answer: This knowledge focuses on Linux privilege escalation. Windows systems require different techniques not covered here.

faq.question: What initial access level is required?
faq.answer: Basic shell access as any unprivileged user (www-data, user, etc.) is sufficient to begin enumeration.

faq.question: How long does typical escalation take?
faq.answer: Layer 1 (quick wins) takes 2-5 minutes. Layer 2 (linpeas) takes 5-15 minutes. Layer 3 varies.

faq.question: Is this safe to use on production systems?
faq.answer: No. This is for authorized penetration testing and CTF environments only. Always obtain proper authorization.

faq.question: Does this work on containers?
faq.answer: Limited. Container escapes require specific conditions (docker socket access, privileged containers). See the Docker escape section.

faq.question: How does this differ from automated tools?
faq.answer: This knowledge guides systematic manual enumeration. Automated tools like linpeas complement but do not replace methodology.
